description: From Middle English animate, from Latin animatus, past participle of animare (“to fill with breath, quicken, encourage, animate”), from anima (“breath”); see anima.

adjectives.description: animate (comparative more animate, superlative most animate)

entries.meaning: Possessing the quality or ability of motion.

examples: She is an engaging and animate speaker.

entries.meaning: (grammar, of a noun or pronoun) having a referent that is considered alive (this generally includes humans and animals, often also gods, plants, etc.)
examples: Nouns can be singular or plural, and one of two genders, animate or inanimate.

entries.meaning: (grammar) Inflected to agree with an animate noun or pronoun.

verbs.description: animate (third-person singular simple present animates, present participle animating, simple past and past participle animated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To impart motion or the appearance of motion to.
examples: If we animate the model, we can see the complexity of the action.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give spirit or vigour to; to stimulate or enliven; to inspirit.
examples: The more to animate the people, he stood on high  […]  and cried unto them with a loud voice.
